message.content:
We start by extracting the needed amounts from the three statements.

Step 1. Operating Cash Flow to Net Income Ratio  
• From the cash‐flow statement we have the “Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities”: –1,919,526.63  
• From the income statement the “Net Profit” is: 99,532.29  
• The ratio is computed as:  
  Operating Cash Flow to Net Income Ratio = (Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities) / (Net Profit)  
  = –1,919,526.63 / 99,532.29 ≈ –19.28

Step 2. Current Assets Turnover Ratio  
The sample “turnover ratio” used the Total Revenue divided by the Total Current Assets (at period end).  
• From the income statement, “Total Revenue” = 836,813.79  
• From the balance sheet, “Total Current Assets” at end = 10,453,882.43  
• Thus, the ratio is:  
  Current Assets Turnover Ratio = 836,813.79 / 10,453,882.43 ≈ 0.08

Step 3. Quick Ratio  
The Quick Ratio is calculated as (Cash + Cash Equivalents + Short-term Receivables) divided by (Current Liabilities). Here we add the following quick assets:  
  Cash on Hand, Bank Deposits, Interest Receivable, and Accounts Receivable.  
• Quick Assets = 2,105,753.37 + 559,055.66 + 6,494.02 + 335,639.38  
  = 2,105,753.37 + 559,055.66 = 2,664,809.03  
  2,664,809.03 + 6,494.02 = 2,671,303.05  
  2,671,303.05 + 335,639.38 = 3,006,942.43  
• Current Liabilities = Accounts Payable + Taxes Payable = 5,596,070.00 + 41,840.70 = 5,637,910.70  
• Therefore:  
  Quick Ratio = 3,006,942.43 / 5,637,910.70 ≈ 0.53

Thus, the final answers are:

{
  "solution": {
    "Operating Cash Flow to Net Income Ratio": "-19.28",
    "Current Assets Turnover Ratio": "0.08",
    "Quick Ratio": "0.53"
  }
}
